top_categories.workout_context: 497 miles. Your legs will beg to quit after 120. This trains the power output you need from mile 130 onward.
52,493ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 497 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
Badlands' Desert gravel, Alpine passes forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 497 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Badlands' demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before August.
497 miles rewards fat oxidation. This volume work shifts your fuel mix so you're still burning fat at hour 5, not bonking at hour 3.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Badlands, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
At Badlands, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
52,493ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
106ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 52,493ft of climbing on desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails does to your power file on race day.

race_overlay.heat: August in Granada, Andalusia, Spain — August in Andalusia is brutal. Desert sections reach 40-45°C (104-113°F). Pico Veleta at 3,396m can drop to 5-10°C at night with potential freezing. 30-40°C temperature swings in a single day. Afternoon thunderstorms in mountains possible. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Badlands — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day. Race-day realities: Extreme heat in desert (40°C+).
race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 497 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 497 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.altitude: Badlands with 52,493ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Alpine cold at altitude.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Badlands demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: desert gravel, alpine passes, technical mtb trails. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 497 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, VO2max, and Endurance to prepare you for 497 miles of desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails in Granada, Andalusia, Spain.
